items.title: 5 European nations say Alexei Navalny was poisoned by Kremlin
items.summary_auto: Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny was poisoned by the Kremlin with a lethal toxin derived from the skin of poison dart frogs, five European countries said Saturday.

items.title: Amid 'Buy Canadian' fervour, Canada's top pension funds still heavily invested in U.S.
Are you an early bird or a night owl? Why scientists are moving beyond these groupings
items.summary_auto: Categorizing people into just two groups — late and early risers — may be oversimplified when it comes to health and behaviour.

items.title: Cheating, a proposal, cute couples — but are the Olympics really the place for love?
items.summary_auto: Love often seems to be in the air during the Olympics. And there's a storied history of Olympic declarations of love, Olympic couples, and the sometimes controversial Olympic proposal.

items.title: ‘We’re so vulnerable’: How Canadians can cope with anxiety in the face of existential threats from the U.S.
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump’s second term has threatened Canada with annexation and economic ruin, leaving some Canadians feeling anxious and concerned. A Winnipeg therapist offers strategies for coping with those emotions.

items.title: Does your local school lock its doors? Why school entrance protocols vary across Canada
items.summary_auto: This week's tragedy in Tumbler Ridge, B.C., and  other intruder incidents in schools are reviving conversations across Canada about school safety — including controlled access and entry procedures.

items.title: From umbrella to uncertainty: Europe and Canada's nuclear deterrence anxiety
items.summary_auto: European allies are quietly exploring closer nuclear deterrence ties with France amid growing anxiety about the long-term reliability of U.S. security guarantees. Germany and Poland have acknowledged early-stage talks with Paris, while French President Emmanuel Macron has opened the door to a strategic dialogue — without offering a formal nuclear umbrella.

items.title: Winter slips can be especially dangerous for seniors. This Quebec judo school teaches them how to fall safely
items.summary_auto: Dojo Blainville has designed a program for seniors to help prevent injury in the case of a fall.

items.title: Being Jamaican in Canada meant we didn’t talk about mental health — until depression forced me to
items.summary_auto: When Bria Barrows was diagnosed with depression as a high school student, her family struggled to talk about mental health issues. Since then, she has learned that talking leads to healing.

items.title: Bart Layton didn't like Chris Hemsworth for Crime 101. Then he proved him wrong
items.summary_auto: Coming after his critically acclaimed documentary The Imposter, and genre-defying American Animals, director Bart Layton just released his deceptively deep heist film Crime 101. While he didn't initially believe Chris Hemsworth could pull off the role, he told CBC the Australian actor proved him wrong.

items.title: From Heated Rivalry to Wuthering Heights, book-to-screen adaptations cause a boom in book sales
items.summary_auto: Canadian booksellers are noticing that sales for book-to-screen adaptations are now having a moment like never before. Booksellers say that social media fandoms and streaming services are driving this phenomenon.

items.title: Mario Tennis Fever doesn't change the formula much, but rallies are so good it barely matters
items.summary_auto: Mario Tennis Fever stays true to a formula as solid as it was on the Nintendo 64 decades ago: best played on a couch with friends.

items.title: Trump says regime change 'seems' to be 'best thing that could happen' for Iran
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump on Friday embraced potential regime change in Iran and declared that "tremendous power" will soon be in the Middle East, as the Pentagon sent a second aircraft carrier to the region.

items.title: How communities across B.C. and Canada are showing love and support for Tumbler Ridge
items.summary_auto: Canadian communities, small and large, have been expressing condolences and gestures of support this week, in the wake of a mass shooting in Tumbler Ridge, B.C., that killed eight victims, including six children.

items.title: B.C. man sentenced to life in prison for stabbing death of young mother
items.summary_auto: A B.C. Supreme Court Justice has delivered the sentence for Zain Wood who was convicted of of  first-degree murder in the stabbing of 22-year-old, Prince George, B.C., mother Isabelle Thomas in front of her two children in 2023.

items.title: Labelling Palestine Action a terrorist group was unlawful, Britain’s High Court rules
items.summary_auto: Britain's High Court says the U.K. government acted unlawfully when it designated the protest group Palestine Action as a terrorist organization. But the fate of protesters arrested under the Terrorism Act still hangs in the balance.

items.title: Seasonique, Seasonale birth control pills recalled over possible missing blister card
items.summary_auto: Teva Canada is recalling two lots of Seasonique and one lot of Seasonale prescription birth control pills as a precaution after the company received a complaint about a package missing an entire blister card of pills, Health Canada says.

items.title: The ‘Arc de Trump’ | About That
items.summary_auto: Andrew Chang explains why U.S. President Donald Trump wants to build a 250-foot-high 'Independence Arch' in Washington, D.C., and why it’s under heavy scrutiny. Images provided by The Canadian Press, Reuters and Getty Images

items.title: Manitoba issues blanket measles warning for 5 southern RMs, says fans were exposed at Jets game
items.summary_auto: Manitoba saw 44 confirmed cases of measles during the first week of February, as well as an exposure at the Feb. 4 Winnipeg Jets game, the province's latest measles reports say.

items.title: Canada, Denmark deepen defence ties after Greenland annexation threat
items.summary_auto: Canada and Denmark have signed a new defence co-operation agreement aimed at strengthening Arctic security amid lingering tensions over U.S. annexation threats toward Greenland. The pact enhances collaboration on surveillance and joint operations but does not go beyond existing NATO Article 5 commitments.

items.title: Mexico probing whether B.C. mining company was responsible in kidnapping of its workers
items.summary_auto: Mexico’s Attorney General’s Office is investigating whether a Canadian mining company holds any responsibility in the suspected cartel kidnapping of 10 of its workers, President Claudia Sheinbaum said Friday.

items.title: Former minister Freeland violated election rules during 2024 byelection, watchdog finds
items.summary_auto: Former deputy prime minister and cabinet minister Chrystia Freeland violated election rules during a 2024 byelection, the Commissioner of Canada Elections said on Friday.

items.title: What we know — and don't — about the guns used in the Tumbler Ridge, B.C., shooting
items.summary_auto: Three days after one of the deadliest mass shootings in Canada's history, it's still unclear how the shooter, who had a history of mental illness, got hold of the guns recovered at the two crime scenes.

items.title: Indian man pleads guilty in New York over alleged plot against Sikh separatist
items.summary_auto: An Indian man pleaded guilty on Friday to ‌U.S. criminal charges that he orchestrated a failed Indian government-backed plot to kill a Sikh separatist in New York ‌City, in connection with what U.S. and Canadian authorities have called a broader effort to target Indian dissidents.

items.title: Democrats launching probe into Trump, Lutnick links with Moroun after Gordie Howe bridge threat
items.summary_auto: Democrats in Washington say they’re launching an investigation into the Trump administration and its links to the wealthy owner of the Ambassador Bridge after the U.S. president threatened to block the opening of the competing Gordie Howe Bridge earlier this week.
